review_blob: Super luscious black stuff, vanilla, bourbon - right amount of sweetness, like liquid cake. Superb stuff!

Got this on a few days after bottling. 
Wow, what a wonderfully hoppy nose! Lots of butter and creamy lactic notes (guess from the sorachi ace?) which might become a bit much, but other than that this is a top notch hop bomb, grassy, peachy, a bit on the sweet side. Delicious..!

Very piny and lots of citrus, I get some buckthorn bitterness and spicy sourness as well. Pours hazy with big bubbly head. Quite bitter and slight sweet behind all the fruity hoppiness. Dont get too much mango though, maybe a bit in the aftertaste. This one lingers. Great DIPA!
beer_name: Brewski / All In Brewing / Cigar City Culebra

review_blob: Hazy straw with fuzzy white head - aroma is super resiny, lots of grassy hoptones, almost as if theres too many hops fighting eachother out. Very fresh. Lomen, peach, mango pops out, quite piny, very, very bitter. I could go on drinking this all night.
Really piny nose, soapy head, clear amber - taste is quite resiny, piny, citrussy and smooth. Very nice, very drinkable.

This one was most probably infected, which made it the more enjoyable for me - had an almost perfect nose - rosepettels, citrus, pear and apple - almost champagne like in a way, but smoother and less alchoholic. Taste was tart, a bit off, but mostly just fresh and sour, almost like a cider. More so than a lambic.
beer_name: Maasland Ons Bier een Wageningse Tripel

review_blob: Bottle from Cantillon Brewery. Super wonderfully sour, finding the rhubarb is like playing hide and seek, it appears slightly at the end of a sniff and then disappears to sometimes pop up a bit in the far back corner of your mouth. I dont know, not the perfect rhubarb sour, but damn delicious.

Cantillon never does a bad job, but this one didnt really impress me so much. Sure, its sour, has that Cantillon taste to it, but a bit hard to specify, you could say a bit murky in taste. But damn delicious for what it is, just nothing special in a Cantillon catalogue.

Really amazing framboise, had opportunity to compare it with Boons Farmbiose on tap, which tasted like sugar candy in comparrison. All you need to know is that it is a Cantillon framboise that beats Ros de Gambrinus with a good amount. So yeah, gotta try it.

This is the rating for the 2014 edition which is the best one Ive had, the other years Ive tried varies between 3.9 and 4.3.
Very intense beer, you get that its a Cantillon right away, very fruity, but not overwhelmingly so - compared to for instance the Mikkeller double blueberry, which is more like a perfect blueberry drink of fruitiness. This one has more edge, you get to taste parts of the blueberry you cant normally taste, but in this super exposed way you can. I love this one, feel grateful it comes out in my neighborhood every year.
Super crisp IPA, good bitterness, the mosaic shines through here and there, otherwise the citra is dominant. Nice and fresh!

Booom!!! Very big Gueuze, havent had a beer like this for a long time. Very intense in the nose, its like the funky sour hay-thing transcends into something else, very fresh sour apples, sourdough gone bad and vinegar. Tthe taste produces sunshine behind my closed eyelids - just incredible! Really worth the wait and money!

Tap@Fermentoren. Very decent IPA, very much middle of the road on the malts and hops, not very bitter, but lots of fruitiness and resiny hoppiness. Pilsner malt backbone, lots of amarillo and citra notes. Great session IPA.

Bottle, 2010. For me this is a very straight, middle of the road sour. Super delicious, but in the light of other sours Ive had recently, this one seems a bit too straight forward for me to turn back to. But Id always enjoy it and recommend it to anyone who wants a good, sour, funky Gueuze.

Tap, Fermentoren. A nice big IIPA, could be a bit drier, but I actually dont mind the sweetness in this, since its balanced out nicely by the bitterness and citra dry hopping.
Pours dark amber, nose is all them tropical fruits, you know em, same with the taste. Very good for a 9,1% beer, could imagine though that it would age particularly bad, due to the sweetness thats hidden behind the hops.

Bottle from Toft Vin - 18/07/14. 
 I guess this is it, even though the label only mentions the bourbon aging, no specific kind. Red wax sealing.
 Poured down the middle, shows a nice inch-thick, quickly fading foam - brown and bubbly. Black with red edges. Aroma escapes the glass way before I even approach it; I almost get a barleywine sort of sweetness and dried fruitiness, coated in chocolaty bourbon. Putting my nose into the tulip the bourbon overshadows most, but I get a very dense, compact and full aroma that tells me something merged nicely in this one. First sip is velvety and smooth, very sweet and chocolaty, the bourbon almost too dominant, but I kind of like that. Lots of alcohol, but again in a nice imperial stout kind of way: the heat lingers on the palate - as it should in an 11% stout. I like it. Its not the plate reinvented, it doesnt go super deep or crazy, but its a solid, creamy, smooth imperial stout and the barrel aging really provided with some good finish. Well done!
beer_name: De Molen Hel & Verdoemenis Wild Turkey BA

review_blob: Tap at Fermentoren. Pours hazy apricot with soapy head. Strong bretty aroma, very nice; peaches, strawberries and funky hay. Mouthfeel a bit watery and very low carbonation. Taste is fresh and bertty, hoppy and slightly bitter. Ends on a creamy peachy note. High drinkability and very tasty stuff!
beer_name: Croocked Moon Simplistic Pimp Shit IPA

review_blob: Bottle from Fish & Beer (Bottled 04-26-2012) pours reddish, slightly hazy with good, soapy head. Aroma is oak and lots of it, brett, sour berries (red currants, overripe goose berries). Quite big in mouth, fizzes up and sinks smoothly. Taste is sour, oak, same as aroma with a bit of raisins and vanilla. Well worth the money, and way better than the canned version! Cheers!

Tap at Fermentoren. Pours golden, slightly hazy, with lacy white head. Aroma is fresh; grapefruit and apricot with a pilsnerish crispiness. Sadly I detect a slight hint of diacetyl in this keg, had it often before without that scent, so will try not to let it trump this rating. Taste is quite similar, almost like an IPA backbone, without much further width. Fruity, without any specifics, bitter in a smooth, not overpowering way. A bit boring really. Had it before where I was a lot more excited, dont know the age of this batch, perhabs that has something to say. Anyway, may not deserve the 3,2, but gets it for old times sake.

Tap at Fermentoren. Pours black, deep brown/red when seen in front of light, with a light hazel head. Aroma of citrus, pineapple and burned malts, massive cocoa all of a sudden, baked apples - really gentle mix of aromas, could smell this one for ages! Lots of toasted malts, coffeish cocoa darkness and bitterness. Could do with some (more?) dryhopping I feel, but perhabs it would over trump the subtle toasty notes. Not being a big black IPA fan, I really dig this one! Not to heavy, sticky or sweet. You keep finding new tastes in there, just got a huge creamy peach wave - awesome!

Tap at Fermentoren. Pours deep orange, slightly hazy with an off-white, lacy head. Aroma is - I actually almost only get peach and mango. Kind of simplistic, but also nice. After a bit of time in the glass I get some malty sweetness, brown sugar and a bit of alcohol as well. Sweet and bitter tasting, I get overripe peaches that clearly derives from a fusion of malts and hops, and some grapefruity bitterness and sourness at the end. Surprisingly simple for a strong IPA, but very drinkable and neat.

Tap at Fermentoren. Pours slightly hazy, yellow/golden with a lacy white, big-bobbled head. Aroma jumps in your face; melon, pear and most of all something as unusual as custard apples. Taste is more mellow, its a lager after all, salty, more grapefruit and pineapple, but still mostly the same as in the aroma. Close to no bitterness, lingers on your toungue with a crisp pilsner-malt feeling that induces another sip. Gorgeous beer for the sun!

Tap at Fermentoren. Pours hazy hay-golden with a solid, white soapy head. Aroma of lemon-peel, yuzu (or at least how yuzu-beers always smell!) - reminds me of Westbrooks Gozu. A bit of diacetyl at the end. Taste is sour, bitter in the back of mouth, salty and sour in front. I get a lot of diacetyl, perhabs its just this keg - reading the other ratings, I think this one might be a bit off. As my mouth gets used to the tastes I begin to notice some hoppiness, but its very deep down and not worth the trouble. Not for me.

Bought this quite a few times when in Montral, May 2013, 2006 edition. Aroma of unripe apples, fresh hay and brett. Carbonation is low, mouthfeel similarly thin. Starts out quite sour, but ends on a malty sweet note, you have to look for the aging even though this was 7 years old. A bit too simple, but the only decent gueuze I had in Canada.

Bottle from Dpanneur Peluso. Nice pour, big white, fluffy head. Aroma is wheaty, fruity (citrus, peach) and sweet, typical saison. A bit sourness in the taste, but more of the heavier wheaty notes, maple and yeast. Overall a nice saison, but nothing out of the ordinary.
beer_name: Dunham / Kissmeyer La Rsurrection de Broderus

review_blob: Pours light and golden with a white soapy head that fades rather fast. Aroma is like lemonade, champagne, citrus, pineapple. Taste is the same, but less clean and with a salty background. Theres a wheat-malty spine on which everything else is attached, including the tart sourness. Its fizzy and sparkling in your mouth, but thin, like sparkling water. Overall very enjoyable, imagine it would be perfect on a warm summer day. Nice!

Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends. Pours clear with a good, white and soapy head. SMells like gummy bears (the white ones), I can find the tea which plays well with the brett. Has almost a white wine creamy sourness to the aroma too. Taste is a less intense version of that, plus a bit of hops and more brett. Very nice, almost like candy.

Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends 29/12/13. Pours black with red edges, nice creamy brown head. Smells sweet and roasty, coffee, vanilla, fudge and a vague fruity hoppiness underneath. Taste is sweet and caramely, slightly sour and bitter. Quite smooth and pleasant, the 10,5 is more than very well hidden. A tan to sweet and I cant find all those hops that supposedly is in it.

(24/11/13, Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends, CPH) Pours clear deep orange with a bubbly head. Aroma of malts, alcohol, lots of grapefruit, a bit of mango, pear and orange. Quite sweet taste, very smooth, grapefruit with a slight bitterness, not as fresh or hoppy as I had expected, and has a weird malty-burned body. Was told this was fairly fresh, doesnt taste so though.

(Bottle from Mikkeller & Friends) Pours all clear and golden with a big but quickly fading, frothy head. Smells nice and flowery for a pilsner, but still with a evident pilsner background. Good full and carbonated mouthfeel, quite bitter and a little sweet is the first two thoughts to appear. Get some crispiness from the malts and some citrus from the hops, but thats it. Good pilsner, boring if youre looking for something more.

(Draft at Mikkeller & Friends, Nov. 13) Black with a hazel brown, lasting head. Aroma of liquorice, plums, sweet roastiness and port wine. The mouthfeel is dense and oily with sweetness and lots of bitterish liquorice and booze. Theres dark, dried fruits, port and some nutmeggy/cinammonny cake-feeling I cant put a finger on, maybe its the coffee.
beer_name: Mikkeller Ct C Ph Bia (Port Barrel)

review_blob: (Tap at Toronado, Aug. 2013) Beautiful beer and by far the best tequila BA stout Ive had. Its spicy, its dark, sweet and thick, its creamy and its strong! Just an incredibly enjoyable imp. stout, so pick it up if you get the chance!

(11/11/13 Bottle from Khioskh, KBH) Pours pitch black with a rather quick fading brown/grey head and a sprinkly sound. Has a surprisingly fresh aroma, almost like limesoda in the beginning, followed by toasted nuts and coffee, chocolate and vanilla. I actually dont get any bourbon. Taste is chocolaty, like the not BA one, with a boozy bourbon hint and some bitterness. Theres quite the liquorice feeling as well as some coffee, roasted nuts and caramel. Not a lot of bourbon though. Been drinking a lot of good stouts recently, and this doesnt really get up there.
beer_name: Amager / Mikkeller Hr. Frederiksen Vsel Brunch BA

review_blob: Nice, fresh beer for a summers day in the park. Hoppy and slight, very slight tartness in the nose, more so in the mouth. Pine, citrus and mild belgians yeasty tones. Not a masterpiece, but a very enjoyable one!

A tinge too sweet for me, but cant deny that this is a really amazing creation. Full on in every aspect, but still very well balanced. I wish I liked this style more, then it would go way beyond 3.5 thats for sure.

I really enjoyed this beer! By far the most chocolaty beer Ive tried, almost more than chocolate itself! Like drinking carbonated chocolate fudge with alcohol, you can actually slide a finger inside the empty glass and itll be black and sticky! Wonderful, in my top 3 over Canadian beers for sure!
beer_name: Flying Monkeys BNL Imperial Chocolate Stout

review_blob: Very nice, probably my favorite Dieu de Ciel. Lots of saison yeastiness, good amount of coffee and roasted malts, chocolate and a wide range of fruits. The best black saison Ive had too.

Crazy one! Pours like any other IPA, but the aroma is packed with complexity! A lot of hoppy fruitiness together with a range of herbs; salvia, thyme and even anise. Same with the taste, even got a salvia-like bitterness. Hard to pin down, but a truly interesting brew. Kind of blows your mind in a mild way, and for that alone Ill rate this a bit higher than the actual taste is maybe worth.
beer_name: Omnipollo Nathalius Single Hop Galaxy IIPA

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: One of the least tasting beers I ever had. Totally stripped of any taste, 100% forgettable if it wasnt for the disappointment. Has a very slight malt going on and a bit of citrus, but other than that Im very puzzled about how they managed to make it so anonymous - I couldnt do it! But Id almost rather have a beer that tastes bad, just to get some character; had a sip of paulaner while drinking this and it seemed packed with taste in comparison. Good call to use this for a base to brett in their Saint version though.

(Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF) Pitch black with brown big bubbly head. Aroma is light and slightly tart, chocolate and weak vanilla. Taste is classic porter, light and fruity with toasted malts and chocolate (and lots of it) leaving behind a mild bitterness. Pleasant.

(Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF) This is a crazy one! Pours beautifully like hazy amber with an everlasting big bubbly head. The aroma is out of this world! Tremendously fresh like a slightly tart fruit bowl - very, very weak saison-german-bubblegum-yeast thing - like smelling an orange cream colored rose, freshly sprinkled with the purest dram. Very upfront peach/apricot. The taste is absolutely different; extremely carbonated foaming explosively - almost salty with bergamot, an explosion of earl grey tea that disappears like sea foam, leaving a tenuous bitterness. Aroma is heaven, taste slightly disappointing.

(Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF - Batch no. 1) The colour of this one is very mesmerizing; like a very early orange-red sunrise seen through a fair fog. The aroma is extremely saliva inducing - so sour, you get the wood and the sour cherries - the word "spontaneous" pops up hard. The taste; insanely sour, followed by by discrete wood and slight sweetness. Like a very sour red wine with sourdough bacterias. Not too complex, but heavenly tart!

(Aug. 2013, bottle from Bottleworks, SF) Pours bright amber, crystal clear. Aroma is quite light, sprite-like, hops, lychee and pineapple with an underlying sticky-sweet malt. The taste is where it takes the wrong direction. there is some fruit and citrus from the hop, but very fleeting, followed by a bitter and sweet richness that disappears almost as soon at it appears. Not a bad beer, but a bad IPA and a forgettable experience.

(Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF) Pours like a very liquidy, fair acacia honey. The aroma is full and sweet, like a blossoming flower field with some classic Belgian yeast added. Taste is sweet, easy and soft, slightly bitter - not sour enough for my idea of a saison. Nice and clean, but nothing special.
beer_name: Evil Twin Ryan And The Beaster Bunny

review_blob: (Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF) Pours hazy orange. Aroma of pine needles, chewing gum, barley malt, belgian yeast and tangerine. Taste is unbelievably less interesting - where did all those scents go? Just a watery bitterness and some toasted malts. Not that bad, but still uninteresting.

(Aug. 2013, draft at Toronado and bottle various places, SF) One of my favorites, of not the favorite, in the pale ale department. Pours slightly hazy, golden like a hayfield on a summers day. Aroma is like a "best of hops"; sharp apricot, peach, pineapple, green and herbal, spicy and piny, a fair amount of sticky marijuana, super fresh. Taste is dry, super fruity hops, how your brain would reconstruct an IPA in a dream, just super crisp and loads of hash and hops. One of the best things about this beer is that you always get it fresh, so its bound to always be good. A timeless classic for sure!

(Aug. 2013, draft at City Beer, SF) Golden apricot appearance. Aroma is an explosion of tropical fruits - fresh, sweet and hoppy as f***! Taste is slightly malted, hoppy hops, has a distinguished dry hop character, green, fresh and sweet. Slightly boozy and malty finish.

(29. Oct. 2013, bottle from Kihoskh, CPH) Pours fair and golden and orange, slightly hazy. Aroma is pilsner malt up front, grass and some sweet hoppiness down there at the bottom. Taste is very crisp, pilsner malt, lots of citrus, a bit sweet, a little puff of bitterness in the end, but nothing special. more of a session beer than an IPA tastewise - definitely dont taste the alcohol. Not a good IPA, but an enjoyable pilsner for sure.
beer_name: To l Ridiculously Close To Sanity

review_blob: (Aug. 2013, bottle at City Beer, SF) First of all: sorry, but this isnt my favourite style. Pours almost impervious, ruby and dark brown. Aroma is red and port wine, raisins, sweet and sour with a bit of cinnamony spiciness in the end. Very rich mouth feel, liqueur followed by red wine, begins sour, turns sweet and very warm. Quite dry. Fermented raisins. Very nice for the style, but too boozy and sweet for my liking.

(Aug. 2013, draft at City Beer, SF) Appears hazy read with a hint of purple. Aroma is slightly tart, blueberries and pomegranate. Taste is very disappointing; tastes like a carbonated red lemonade, watery, mildly sour and sweet. Ok, but very forgettable.
beer_name: Evil Twin Justin Blbr (Brunello Wine Barrel Aged)
